sets.title: RCVS Farm Animal Mock Exam – 50 MCQs

questions.stem: A dairy herd reports 4 abortions in 60 cows over 3 weeks. Annual abortion rate is 4%. Most appropriate interpretation?

options.text: Below intervention threshold – no action required
Cluster suggests infectious cause despite annual rate

questions.explanationShort: A cluster in a short time suggests infectious abortion even if annual rate is under 5%.
questions.explanationLong: RCVS often tests that temporal clustering (several abortions in weeks) is suspicious for infectious causes and should trigger investigation, even when the annual percentage looks ‘acceptable’.

questions.stem: Which finding most strongly suggests infectious rather than non-infectious abortion?
questions.explanationShort: Clustering in time is a classic infectious red flag.
questions.explanationLong: A tight cluster suggests an infectious process (e.g., BVD/IBR/lepto etc.). Non-infectious causes are often sporadic unless there’s a clear shared exposure.

questions.stem: Most useful material to increase diagnostic yield in abortion investigation:
questions.explanationShort: Fetus + placenta/membranes gives the best chance of diagnosis.
questions.explanationLong: Many pathogens and lesions are in placenta. Submitting fetus and membranes improves lab yield substantially.

questions.stem: Which infection commonly causes abortion without clinical signs?
questions.explanationShort: BVD can cause reproductive loss with minimal maternal signs.
questions.explanationLong: BVD infections can be clinically silent in the dam yet cause embryonic loss, abortion, congenital defects, or PI calves depending on timing.

questions.stem: Statutory abortion investigation in UK is focused on:
questions.explanationShort: Bovine abortions are reported primarily for brucellosis surveillance.
questions.explanationLong: In the UK, abortion reporting is especially linked to statutory brucellosis investigation (historically important, high consequence).

questions.stem: Brucella abortus is most heavily shed in:
questions.explanationShort: Highest load is in abortion material and uterine discharges.
questions.explanationLong: Brucella is massively shed at abortion/calving via placenta, fluids, and uterine discharges—highly infectious to herd mates and people.

questions.stem: Following abortion due to brucellosis, cow will:

options.text: Often calve normally but continue shedding

questions.explanationShort: May calve normally later but remain infectious.
questions.explanationLong: A classic exam point: later pregnancies may look normal, but infected cattle may still shed around parturition.

questions.stem: In BVD, infection at 90 days gestation results in:
questions.explanationShort: Before ~110–120 days → immune tolerance → PI calf.
questions.explanationLong: Infection before fetal immune competence can produce persistently infected calves that shed virus lifelong (main reservoir).

questions.stem: Mucosal disease is fatal because:

options.text: Cytopathic strain superinfection in PI animal

questions.explanationShort: Occurs in PI animals when cytopathic virus is involved.
questions.explanationLong: Mucosal disease is essentially a catastrophic BVD syndrome in PI animals; it’s classically fatal.

questions.stem: The most effective BVD eradication strategy:

options.text: Identification and removal of PI animals

questions.explanationShort: Remove PI animals to stop ongoing transmission.
questions.explanationLong: Vaccination supports control but eradication requires identifying and removing PIs (main within-herd source).

questions.stem: Target % cows calving of mated in 9-week breeding period:
questions.explanationShort: A common KPI target is ≥95% calving of mated cows.
questions.explanationLong: Compact calving drives uniform calf crop and profitability. >5% barren/poor calving performance prompts investigation.

questions.stem: Cow must conceive within how many days postpartum to maintain 12-month calving interval?
questions.explanationShort: 82 days postpartum is the classic target for a 12-month interval.
questions.explanationLong: 365 days − 283 days gestation ≈ 82 days. This number comes up a lot in farm exam questions.

questions.stem: Most important factor affecting length of postpartum anoestrus:
questions.explanationShort: Suckling is the biggest driver of prolonged postpartum anoestrus.
questions.explanationLong: Multiple factors affect cyclicity, but suckling is classically the major one; low BCS also prolongs anoestrus.

questions.stem: Heifer should reach what % mature bodyweight before breeding?
questions.explanationShort: Target around 65% mature weight before breeding.
questions.explanationLong: Heifers at ~65% mature BW are more likely to have reached puberty/cycling. Underweight heifers have poorer conception and later calving.

questions.stem: >5% assisted calvings is associated with:
questions.explanationShort: High dystocia/assistance rates reduce fertility performance.
questions.explanationLong: Assisted calvings increase postpartum disease and delay return to cyclicity, reducing conception rates and compact calving performance.

questions.stem: Main cause of dystocia in beef herds:
questions.explanationShort: Most common cause is oversized calves (fetopelvic disproportion).
questions.explanationLong: Often linked to sire choice, heifer size, and nutrition. Prevention uses easy-calving genetics and appropriate heifer growth targets.

questions.stem: Optimal BCS at calving (beef cow):
questions.explanationShort: BCS 2.5–3 is generally optimal at calving.
questions.explanationLong: Too thin → poor fertility/long anoestrus; too fat → dystocia/metabolic issues and wasted feed costs.

questions.stem: Cows with BCS <2 at calving typically show:
questions.explanationShort: Low BCS delays return to cyclicity postpartum.
questions.explanationLong: Negative energy balance and poor body reserves prolong postpartum anoestrus and reduce conception rates.

questions.stem: Bull scrotal circumference target at 24 months:
questions.explanationShort: A common target is ~34 cm at 24 months.
questions.explanationLong: Scrotal circumference correlates with semen output and earlier puberty in female offspring. Targets vary slightly by breed.

questions.stem: Most likely cause of temporary testicular degeneration:
questions.explanationShort: Fever can temporarily damage spermatogenesis.
questions.explanationLong: Spermatogenesis is temperature sensitive. Fever/systemic illness can impair semen quality for weeks afterwards.

questions.stem: BRSV primarily affects:
questions.explanationShort: Commonest in young calves (often <6 months).
questions.explanationLong: BRSV is a major component of bovine respiratory disease in youngstock; adults can be affected but calves are typical.

questions.stem: Most characteristic lesion of BRSV:
questions.explanationShort: Diffuse interstitial pneumonia is typical.
questions.explanationLong: BRSV causes interstitial pneumonia with oedema/emphysema; secondary bacterial bronchopneumonia may complicate cases.

questions.stem: Most rapid and sensitive BRSV diagnostic:
questions.explanationShort: PCR is rapid and practical; culture is difficult.
questions.explanationLong: BRSV isolation is challenging; PCR detects viral nucleic acid quickly from respiratory samples.

questions.stem: Passively derived immunity in BRSV:
questions.explanationShort: Maternal antibodies mainly reduce severity.
questions.explanationLong: Passive immunity does not reliably prevent infection or shedding but can reduce clinical severity and mortality.

questions.stem: Case fatality rate in BRSV outbreaks may reach:
questions.explanationShort: Can be up to around 10–20% in severe outbreaks.
questions.explanationLong: Morbidity is often high; fatality varies with management, secondary infections, and timeliness of treatment.

questions.stem: Bluetongue is transmitted by:
questions.explanationShort: Vector-borne via Culicoides biting midges.
questions.explanationLong: Bluetongue epidemiology depends on midge distribution/activity; it’s not primarily spread by animal-to-animal direct contact.

questions.stem: Most important differential for Bluetongue:
questions.explanationShort: FMD is the key notifiable differential.
questions.explanationLong: BT can resemble FMD (oral lesions/lameness). FMD has major legal and outbreak implications, so it must be high on the differential list.

questions.stem: Vaccination against BTV-8 protects against:
questions.explanationShort: Bluetongue immunity is largely serotype-specific.
questions.explanationLong: Vaccines are targeted to serotypes; BTV-8 vaccination does not reliably protect against other serotypes.

questions.stem: Ruminal lactic acidosis results from:
questions.explanationShort: Carbohydrate overload → lactic acid production → pH crash.
questions.explanationLong: Sudden grain/concentrate ingestion shifts rumen flora, increases lactate, causes rumen stasis, dehydration, metabolic acidosis, endotoxaemia.

questions.stem: Early acidosis diarrhoea appears:
questions.explanationShort: Often delayed; commonly 12–24 hours after overload.
questions.explanationLong: Early signs may be dullness/ataxia/colic; diarrhoea is often absent initially then becomes profuse as rumen contents alter and gut motility changes.

questions.stem: Most important preventive strategy for acidosis:
questions.explanationShort: Adapt rumen gradually to higher starch diets.
questions.explanationLong: Gradual dietary transition with adequate fibre is the key preventive. Buffers can help but don’t replace correct feeding management.

questions.stem: Listeriosis is most commonly associated with:
questions.explanationShort: Poor silage preservation is the classic risk factor.
questions.explanationLong: Listeria monocytogenes proliferates in poorly fermented silage; outbreaks are linked to feeding such forage.

questions.stem: Classic neurological sign in listeriosis:
questions.explanationShort: Unilateral brainstem signs → circling to affected side.
questions.explanationLong: Brainstem encephalitis causes cranial nerve deficits (e.g., facial paralysis), head tilt, circling/leaning, depression.

questions.stem: Coccidiosis most common age group:
questions.explanationShort: Usually affects young lambs around 4–8 weeks.
questions.explanationLong: Young animals are most susceptible before acquired immunity develops; disease is promoted by crowding and contamination.

questions.stem: Coccidia oocysts are:
questions.explanationShort: Oocysts persist and resist many environmental stresses.
questions.explanationLong: Oocysts survive for long periods and resist many disinfectants; hygiene and reducing stocking density are key controls.

questions.stem: Highly sensitive test with negative result is useful to:
questions.explanationShort: SNOUT: Sensitive test Negative rules OUT disease.
questions.explanationLong: High sensitivity means few false negatives; a negative result makes the disease unlikely.

questions.stem: If prevalence decreases, PPV:
questions.explanationShort: Lower prevalence → more false positives proportionally → PPV drops.
questions.explanationLong: With fewer true cases, a positive test is less likely to be a true positive, reducing PPV.

questions.stem: If prevalence decreases, NPV:
questions.explanationShort: Lower prevalence → more true negatives → NPV rises.
questions.explanationLong: When disease is rare, negative results are more likely to be true negatives.

questions.stem: Sensitivity formula:
questions.explanationShort: Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN).
questions.explanationLong: Proportion of diseased animals correctly identified as positive.

questions.stem: Specificity formula:
questions.explanationShort: Specificity = TN / (TN + FP).
questions.explanationLong: Proportion of non-diseased animals correctly identified as negative.

questions.stem: Minimum withdrawal for meat under cascade:
questions.explanationShort: Statutory minimum meat withdrawal under cascade: 28 days.
questions.explanationLong: When prescribing under cascade in food animals, the vet must set an appropriate withdrawal, at least the statutory minimum (often quoted: 28 days meat).

questions.stem: Minimum withdrawal for milk under cascade:
questions.explanationShort: Statutory minimum milk withdrawal under cascade: 7 days.
questions.explanationLong: Under cascade, the vet must set withdrawal periods; commonly taught minimum for milk (and eggs) is 7 days.

questions.stem: Category 1 ABP includes:
questions.explanationShort: SRM is Category 1 (highest risk).
questions.explanationLong: Category 1 includes SRM and other high-risk materials (e.g., TSE-risk).

questions.stem: Category 2 ABP includes:
questions.explanationShort: Manure is Category 2 ABP.
questions.explanationLong: Category 2 includes manure and GI contents and other higher-risk ABPs that are not Category 1.

questions.stem: Category 3 ABP includes:
questions.explanationShort: Fluke-damaged liver is Category 3 (lowest risk).
questions.explanationLong: Category 3 includes parts from animals fit for slaughter but not for human consumption for local/non-systemic reasons (e.g., localized parasitic lesions).

questions.stem: POM-V medicines require:
questions.explanationShort: POM-V requires vet Rx + clinical assessment under care.
questions.explanationLong: POM-V medicines can only be prescribed by a veterinarian following clinical assessment of animals under their care.

questions.stem: POM-VPS may be prescribed by:
questions.explanationShort: POM-VPS can be prescribed by vet/pharmacist/SQP.
questions.explanationLong: POM-VPS medicines can be supplied by authorised prescribers including SQPs, depending on product class and regulations.

questions.stem: In prescribing cascade, first alternative step is:
questions.explanationShort: First: UK-authorised veterinary product for another species/condition.
questions.explanationLong: Cascade order matters: the first step is usually a UK-authorised veterinary medicine for another species or different indication.

questions.stem: Under cascade, vet must:
questions.explanationShort: Vet must set a withdrawal period (≥ statutory minimum).
questions.explanationLong: The prescriber is legally responsible for specifying an appropriate withdrawal period when using cascade in food-producing animals.

questions.stem: Bluetongue in UK is:
questions.explanationShort: Bluetongue is notifiable in the UK.
questions.explanationLong: It is vector-borne and controlled via surveillance/movement restrictions/vaccination strategies depending on policy.

categories.title: RCVS Farm Animal Mock Exam – 50 MCQs (Set 2)

questions.stem: A cow is found dead, reportedly normal 2 hours earlier. There is a small amount of dark blood from the nostrils and it has not clotted. Best next step?

options.text: Open the carcass to look for internal haemorrhage
Move the carcass away from cattle housing immediately
Do NOT post-mortem; take a blood smear and contact the appropriate authority
Treat in-contact cattle with NSAIDs and isolate the dead cow

questions.explanationShort: Sudden death + unclotted blood is an anthrax red flag: don’t open; get smear + report.
questions.explanationLong: Suspected anthrax cases should not be opened. Diagnosis is supported by a blood smear showing capsulated rods; movement restrictions/reporting apply.

questions.stem: In suspected anthrax, what sample is most appropriate for rapid confirmation?

options.text: Blood smear from a superficial vessel

questions.explanationShort: Blood smear for capsulated rods.
questions.explanationLong: The classic quick check is a blood smear from superficial vessels; post-mortem should be avoided until anthrax is excluded.

questions.stem: Which statement best describes anthrax spread risk in the UK context?

options.text: Primarily spread by respiratory droplets between cattle
Usually acquired from contaminated soil/feed/water; rare but zoonotic

questions.explanationShort: It’s usually environmental exposure; rare but zoonotic.
questions.explanationLong: Anthrax is classically acquired by ingestion of spores from contaminated sources; it’s important but not typically a rapidly spreading contact epidemic.

questions.stem: Which disease is a UK notifiable zoonosis caused by Mycobacterium bovis?
questions.explanationShort: bTB is notifiable and zoonotic.
questions.explanationLong: bTB is a notifiable disease; it can spread between cattle and multiple other species and is a zoonosis.

questions.stem: SICCT (skin test) typically detects bTB infection from approximately:
questions.explanationShort: SICCT: roughly 3–6 weeks post infection.
questions.explanationLong: The commonly tested figure is that SICCT can identify infection from around 3–6 weeks after infection.

questions.stem: Gamma interferon testing for bTB compared to SICCT is best described as:

options.text: Less sensitive and fewer false positives
More sensitive but more false positives
Only useful after clinical signs develop

questions.explanationShort: More sensitive, but more false positives.
questions.explanationLong: Gamma IFN is used as a supplementary test; it can detect more infected animals but typically at the cost of more false positives.

questions.stem: In bTB epidemiology, which is usually the highest-risk transmission route on farms?

options.text: Cattle-to-cattle direct contact is typically the main risk
Only via milk ingestion by calves

questions.explanationShort: Usually cattle-to-cattle contact is the biggest risk.
questions.explanationLong: While wildlife can contribute, cattle-to-cattle spread is typically the most important transmission route to control within herds.

questions.stem: A key practical requirement to deliver a safe, accurate SICCT test is:

options.text: A single operator can do it without restraint
Testing only at pasture with minimal equipment

questions.explanationShort: Handling facilities matter for safety and accuracy.
questions.explanationLong: Safe restraint and consistent injection/reading require good facilities; this is a commonly examined real-world point.

questions.stem: A common reason bTB is detected late clinically is that:

options.text: Disease develops extremely rapidly over hours
Disease can take months–years before clinical signs
It always causes severe diarrhoea early

questions.explanationShort: It’s slow and often subclinical for a long time.
questions.explanationLong: bTB has slow progression; most cases are detected on routine testing rather than obvious early clinical disease.

questions.stem: A herd has repeated sudden deaths with minimal premonitory signs. Which action is most inappropriate?

options.text: Treat all remaining cattle with broad-spectrum antibiotics immediately
Avoid unnecessary carcass opening until key exclusions done

questions.explanationShort: Blanket antibiotics are not a first response to sudden death clusters.
questions.explanationLong: Sudden death triggers notifiable/zoonotic considerations and sampling/reporting pathways; empirical mass antibiotics can delay correct investigation and doesn’t address biosecurity.

questions.stem: Most important diagnostic clinical finding for displaced abomasum is:

options.text: A ‘ping’ on simultaneous percussion and auscultation

questions.explanationShort: DA classically gives a ping.
questions.explanationLong: A ping over characteristic rib spaces is the key field clue for LDA/RDA; volvulus often deteriorates rapidly.

questions.stem: LDA is most common in dairy cows during:
questions.explanationShort: Peak risk is early post-calving.
questions.explanationLong: LDA commonly occurs in early lactation; signs can resemble ketosis (drop in yield, appetite).

questions.stem: Which acid–base pattern is most consistent with LDA/RDA?

options.text: Metabolic alkalosis with hypochloraemia and hypokalaemia

questions.explanationShort: Sequestration of HCl → alkalosis, low Cl and K.
questions.explanationLong: Abomasal outflow issues trap chloride; potassium falls as well. This is a classic exam trap versus primary rumen acidosis.

questions.stem: Compared with LDA, prompt surgery is always required for RDA mainly because:

options.text: RDA has a high risk of progressing to volvulus
RDA is primarily caused by parasites

questions.explanationShort: RDA can rapidly become volvulus.
questions.explanationLong: RDA is a surgical problem because volvulus risk is high and outcome worsens with delay.

questions.stem: Abomasal volvulus is most associated with:

options.text: Rapid deterioration due to vascular compromise and dehydration

questions.explanationShort: Volvulus = shocky, rapid decline.
questions.explanationLong: Vascular compromise drives dehydration, electrolyte changes and severe systemic deterioration.

questions.stem: Kexxtone reduces ketosis risk primarily by:
questions.explanationShort: Monensin shifts rumen VFAs → more propionate → more glucose.
questions.explanationLong: Monensin increases propionic acid, supporting hepatic glucose production and lowering ketosis risk.

questions.stem: Which statement about Kexxtone is most accurate?

options.text: Reduces ketosis risk but does not eliminate it
Only effective after ketosis is established

questions.explanationShort: It reduces risk, not zero.
questions.explanationLong: Exam wording often targets “reduces but does not eliminate risk” and correct timing/use.

questions.stem: Ruminal acidosis prevention focuses most on:

options.text: Abrupt diet change to ‘reset’ rumen flora
Slow feed transitions and maximising forage/fibre

questions.explanationShort: Slow change + fibre is key prevention.
questions.explanationLong: Preventing sudden carbohydrate overload is central; management is the main control point.

questions.stem: Thrombosis of the vena cava is commonly a downstream complication of:

options.text: Liver abscessation (often linked to rumen acidosis)

questions.explanationShort: Usually starts with liver abscesses (often after acidosis).
questions.explanationLong: The infection can spread from liver abscesses to the vena cava → thrombus → emboli to lungs.

questions.stem: Which sign is most characteristic of vena cava thrombosis in cattle?

options.text: Frothy blood around nose/mouth after coughing blood

questions.explanationShort: Haemoptysis with frothy blood is classic.
questions.explanationLong: Pulmonary emboli/abscessation can cause haemoptysis; many collapse and die soon after onset of bleeding.

questions.stem: FECRT is primarily used to assess:

options.text: Whether eggs are present at all
Anthelmintic efficacy by comparing pre- and post-treatment egg counts
Liver fluke burden via blood enzymes

questions.explanationShort: FECRT checks whether a dewormer worked.
questions.explanationLong: It compares faecal egg counts before and after treatment to estimate efficacy and detect resistance.

questions.stem: An individual FECRT is most reliable when pre-treatment egg counts are:

options.text: Only when egg counts are zero

questions.explanationShort: Best reliability when counts are >300 epg.
questions.explanationLong: Low egg counts make percentage reduction noisy and unreliable; higher baseline counts improve validity.

questions.stem: To improve FECRT reliability at group level, a common recommendation is to test at least:
questions.explanationShort: About 10 animals is a common minimum.
questions.explanationLong: Using too few animals increases sampling error; ≥10 is a frequently cited threshold for more reliable group FECRT.

questions.stem: Teladorsagia circumcincta primarily causes pathology by:

options.text: Adult blood feeding causing acute anaemia
Larval damage in abomasal glands → reduced acid production and raised abomasal pH
Migrating through the liver causing fibrosis

questions.explanationShort: Larvae damage abomasal glands and reduce acid.
questions.explanationLong: Larval stages in gastric glands disrupt parietal cells → higher pH → impaired pepsin activation and digestion.

questions.stem: A consequence of increased abomasal pH in Teladorsagia infection is:

options.text: Pepsinogen converts more rapidly to pepsin
Failure of pepsinogen conversion → elevated plasma pepsinogen

questions.explanationShort: High pH → pepsinogen not activated → pepsinogen rises.
questions.explanationLong: This is a classic mechanism question: less acid means less conversion to active pepsin and measurable pepsinogen changes.

questions.stem: In sheep parasitism, subclinical/moderate infection often causes:

options.text: Diarrhoea and poor weight gain/reduced wool production

questions.explanationShort: Performance loss is common even without dramatic illness.
questions.explanationLong: Many GI nematode infections are production-limiting: reduced growth, diarrhoea, poorer fleece output.

questions.stem: Which is the best interpretation of FECRT purpose in resistance control?

options.text: It diagnoses the parasite species definitively
It estimates how effective a chosen anthelmintic was on that farm
It replaces the need for any other monitoring
It is only useful for flukicides

questions.explanationShort: It tells you if the drug worked (or resistance is likely).
questions.explanationLong: FECRT is a field tool to detect reduced efficacy and guide sustainable worming strategies.

questions.stem: Which management change most reduces selection pressure for resistance (general principle)?

options.text: Treating the entire group at fixed monthly intervals year-round
Targeted treatment based on monitoring and risk
Using the same drug class forever without checking efficacy

questions.explanationShort: Targeted treatments reduce unnecessary dosing and resistance pressure.
questions.explanationLong: Monitoring-based strategies reduce blanket dosing and help preserve refugia, slowing resistance development.

questions.stem: A key limitation of egg counts (general) is that they:

options.text: Directly measure tissue larval burden precisely
Can be influenced by immunity and season; don’t always reflect clinical disease
Are always higher in adults than lambs

questions.explanationShort: Egg output doesn’t perfectly match disease burden.
questions.explanationLong: Egg counts reflect shedding and adult stages; immunity, season, and parasite biology can uncouple egg output from pathology.

questions.stem: Which statement is most consistent with Teladorsagia biology in the notes?

options.text: Adults are the main blood-feeding pathogenic stage
Larvae in abomasal glands are key for pathology
It causes disease only when egg counts are zero

questions.explanationShort: Larval stages drive much of the damage.
questions.explanationLong: The notes emphasise larval development in abomasal glands leading to gland damage and pH changes.

questions.stem: The anion gap is used to:

options.text: Differentiate causes of metabolic acidosis by identifying unmeasured anions

questions.explanationShort: It helps classify metabolic acidosis (unmeasured acids).
questions.explanationLong: High anion gap suggests added acids (e.g., lactate/ketones); normal anion gap suggests bicarbonate loss/hyperchloraemia.

questions.stem: Most commonly taught anion gap formula (excluding minor variants) is:
questions.explanationShort: AG = (Na + K) − (Cl + HCO3).
questions.explanationLong: This is the standard exam calculation structure; some variants omit K but the logic is the same.

questions.stem: A raised anion gap metabolic acidosis most strongly indicates:

options.text: Loss of bicarbonate in diarrhoea only
Addition/accumulation of unmeasured acids (e.g., lactate, ketones)
Pure chloride gain as the only mechanism

questions.explanationShort: High AG = added acids.
questions.explanationLong: Unmeasured anions rise when acids accumulate; this is a core conceptual exam distinction.

questions.stem: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis is most consistent with:
questions.explanationShort: Normal AG acidosis often means bicarb loss replaced by chloride.
questions.explanationLong: Classic mechanism: GI bicarbonate loss (diarrhoea) or renal tubular acidosis → chloride rises to maintain electroneutrality.

questions.stem: Which scenario most likely produces high anion gap acidosis?

options.text: Severe hypovolaemic shock with rising lactate
Simple salivary loss from rumination changes only

questions.explanationShort: Shock → lactate → high AG acidosis.
questions.explanationLong: Anaerobic metabolism increases lactate (unmeasured anion), raising anion gap.

questions.stem: In abomasal displacement/volvulus, the typical acid-base trend is:

options.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis is most typical
Metabolic alkalosis due to sequestration of HCl
Respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation is primary

questions.explanationShort: Sequestered HCl → alkalosis.
questions.explanationLong: Classic exam association: hypochloraemic, hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis in DA.

questions.stem: A key electrolyte abnormality in DA cases is typically:
questions.explanationShort: Chloride is often low.
questions.explanationLong: Chloride is sequestered in abomasal fluid; potassium also falls.

questions.stem: Which pattern fits ruminal lactic acidosis more than DA?
questions.explanationShort: Lactic acidosis = metabolic acidosis picture.
questions.explanationLong: Carbohydrate overload causes rumen pH crash and systemic metabolic acidosis; contrasts with abomasal alkalosis.

questions.stem: Which statement best fits “anion gap” conceptually?

options.text: It estimates ‘missing’ negative charges in plasma not routinely measured
It is only used in respiratory disease

questions.explanationShort: It estimates unmeasured anions.
questions.explanationLong: Albumin, lactate, ketones, phosphates, sulphates contribute; shifts help classify metabolic acidosis.

questions.stem: A cow with black tarry faeces + haemoptysis suggests vena cava thrombosis. The underlying driver to prevent is usually:

options.text: Rumen acidosis leading to liver abscesses

questions.explanationShort: Prevent acidosis → fewer liver abscesses.
questions.explanationLong: The condition is often secondary to liver abscessation; prevention focuses on reducing acidosis risk and managing abscess sources.

questions.stem: bTB is shed in multiple secretions. Which combination is correct?

options.text: Mucus/saliva, milk and faeces can all contain bacteria

questions.explanationShort: Multiple routes: mucus/saliva, milk, faeces.
questions.explanationLong: This is why indirect transmission via shared equipment/contractors can occur, though direct contact is commonly most important.

questions.stem: Which statement about bTB detection is most accurate?

options.text: Most infected cattle show obvious signs early
Most infected cattle are identified by routine testing before obvious signs
bTB always causes high fever and diarrhoea

questions.explanationShort: Most are found on surveillance testing.
questions.explanationLong: Clinical disease is often late; routine herd testing finds many cases earlier.

questions.stem: A herd uses “severe interpretation” for SICCT when:

options.text: The herd has no TB history and is low risk
The herd history/risk means you want to maximise detection

questions.explanationShort: Severe = more sensitive approach in higher-risk contexts.
questions.explanationLong: Interpretation threshold changes are used based on herd history to manage risk; exams often test the logic (sensitivity vs specificity).

questions.stem: Compared with SICCT, gamma interferon can identify infection earlier at about:
questions.explanationShort: Gamma IFN can detect earlier: ~1–4 weeks.
questions.explanationLong: Often examined as an advantage: earlier detection, but increased false positives.

questions.stem: Which is the best reason gamma interferon is not used as the sole routine test everywhere?

options.text: It cannot detect infection at all
Higher false positive rate and specific use criteria
It is only useful in sheep

questions.explanationShort: More false positives; used alongside SICCT in specific situations.
questions.explanationLong: It can be very useful but is not a universal replacement because of specificity/cost/logistics and policy criteria.

questions.stem: Typical clinical signs of bTB (when present) may include:

options.text: Weight loss, swollen lymph nodes, chronic cough, chronic mastitis
Acute watery diarrhoea in all cases

questions.explanationShort: Chronic wasting/cough/lymph nodes/mastitis are possible.
questions.explanationLong: Clinical signs are variable and often absent early; these are the classic chronic-type signs when they do occur.

questions.stem: A key biosecurity message for bTB control inside a herd is to prioritise:

options.text: Only wildlife control; ignore cattle movements
Managing cattle-to-cattle spread and indirect contact via equipment/contractors

questions.explanationShort: Control cattle transmission + indirect routes.
questions.explanationLong: Because shedding can occur via secretions, shared equipment and movements are practical control points alongside wider policy measures.

questions.stem: Which statement best matches slaughterhouse surveillance in bTB control?

options.text: It is irrelevant because reactors are never examined
Reactor cattle have post-mortem examination and samples for culture/genotyping

questions.explanationShort: Reactors are examined and sampled.
questions.explanationLong: Post-mortem findings and lab confirmation contribute to surveillance and epidemiology.

questions.stem: In vena cava thrombosis, the most accurate statement on treatment is:

options.text: Curative antibiotic protocols are usually successful
No effective treatment; consider casualty slaughter if appropriate
Surgery is routinely performed on farm

questions.explanationShort: Often no effective treatment.
questions.explanationLong: Prognosis is poor once haemoptysis occurs; management is often salvage/casualty slaughter if welfare and regulations permit.

questions.stem: In vena cava thrombosis, the most common site emboli lodge is:
questions.explanationShort: Emboli commonly lodge in lungs causing abscessation.
questions.explanationLong: Thrombus fragments travel via bloodstream to the pulmonary vasculature → abscesses/pneumonia → haemoptysis.

sets.title: RCVS Equine Mock Exam – 50 MCQs (High Yield)

questions.stem: A 10-year-old gelding with moderate colic has HR 68 bpm, congested MM, CRT 3 seconds, no reflux on NG tube. Rectal exam reveals tight bands across abdomen. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanationShort: Tight bands + high HR = classic large colon volvulus pattern.
questions.explanationLong: Large colon volvulus often causes rapid cardiovascular compromise (tachycardia, congested membranes, prolonged CRT) and tight bands/taeniae palpable per rectum. Lack of reflux makes primary small intestinal obstruction less likely.

questions.stem: Which finding is the strongest indicator of a surgical colic lesion?
questions.explanationShort: Pain that won’t settle is the biggest red flag for surgery.
questions.explanationLong: Repeated/continuous pain despite appropriate analgesia is strongly associated with strangulating or otherwise surgical lesions and often triggers referral/exploration.

questions.stem: A horse with suspected strangulating obstruction has increasing blood lactate. The most appropriate interpretation is:
questions.explanationShort: Rising lactate = worsening perfusion.
questions.explanationLong: Hyperlactataemia reflects anaerobic metabolism from inadequate oxygen delivery (shock, strangulation). Trends are often more informative than single values.

questions.stem: Large colon torsion >360° is most likely to cause:

options.text: Mild intermittent pain and normal mucous membranes
Severe endotoxaemia and rapid cardiovascular deterioration
Profuse reflux as the earliest sign

questions.explanationShort: Severe torsion compromises blood supply → endotoxaemia.
questions.explanationLong: Strangulation of the large colon leads to ischaemia, endotoxin absorption, shock and rapid deterioration; reflux is more typical of proximal small intestinal obstruction.

questions.stem: Best single prognostic indicator in equine colic management (practical clinical setting):

options.text: Trend in plasma lactate over time

questions.explanationShort: Lactate trend is very useful for prognosis/decision-making.
questions.explanationLong: Serial lactate reflects ongoing perfusion and response to fluid resuscitation; persistently high/rising lactate increases suspicion of strangulation and worsens prognosis.

questions.stem: A horse has recurrent mild colic and diarrhoea after turnout in sandy paddock. Best test to confirm sand accumulation?
questions.explanationShort: Radiographs show sand best.
questions.explanationLong: Sand is radiopaque and can be visualised/quantified on radiographs; rectal palpation may miss it depending on location.

questions.stem: Which lesion most commonly results in significant gastric reflux on nasogastric intubation?

options.text: Right dorsal displacement of the colon

questions.explanationShort: Small intestinal obstruction backs fluid up to the stomach.
questions.explanationLong: Proximal intestinal obstruction leads to accumulation of fluid and gas → reflux. Large colon lesions typically do not cause large reflux volumes early.

questions.stem: Post-operative ileus is most strongly associated with:
questions.explanationShort: Small intestine surgery → ileus risk.
questions.explanationLong: Small intestinal manipulation/resection increases inflammatory mediators and dysmotility risk; POI is a key postoperative complication in these cases.

questions.stem: A horse has signs of gastric ulceration. The most likely site of Equine Gastric Ulcer Syndrome (EGUS) in performance horses is:
questions.explanationShort: Squamous ulcers are common in athletes.
questions.explanationLong: Squamous mucosa is poorly protected from acid and is exposed during exercise/fasting; glandular disease has different pathophysiology and can be harder to treat.

questions.stem: Most appropriate first-line treatment for squamous EGUS:
questions.explanationShort: Omeprazole is the main first-line for squamous ulcers.
questions.explanationLong: Proton pump inhibitors (omeprazole) are most effective for acid suppression. Sucralfate may help especially in glandular disease but is not usually first-line alone for squamous disease.

questions.stem: Most common cause of poor performance in racehorses (exam-frequent):
questions.explanationShort: EIPH is a classic performance-limiting condition in racehorses.
questions.explanationLong: EIPH is common in racing Thoroughbreds; diagnosis often uses endoscopy/BAL. RAO is common but classically in stabled older horses, not racehorses.

questions.stem: Recurrent airway obstruction (RAO/heaves) is primarily:
questions.explanationShort: It’s allergic/inflammatory, often triggered by dust/mould.
questions.explanationLong: RAO is an asthma-like syndrome with bronchoconstriction and neutrophilic airway inflammation; management focuses on environmental control plus bronchodilators/corticosteroids.

questions.stem: Strangles is caused by:
questions.explanationShort: Strangles = Strep equi equi.
questions.explanationLong: S. equi subsp. equi causes lymph node abscessation and nasal discharge/pyrexia; S. zooepidemicus is opportunistic and common in respiratory disease but not classic strangles.

questions.stem: “Bastard strangles” refers to:

options.text: Chronic carrier state in guttural pouch

questions.explanationShort: Bastard strangles = internal abscess spread.
questions.explanationLong: Dissemination leads to abscesses in lungs/abdomen/brain etc. Purpura haemorrhagica is an immune-mediated vasculitis complication, but not the definition of “bastard strangles”.

questions.stem: Most appropriate immediate control measure during a suspected strangles outbreak on a yard:

options.text: Treat all horses with antibiotics immediately
Isolate cases, stop movements, and implement testing/monitoring
Vaccinate all horses immediately regardless of status
Allow training to continue if pyrexia is controlled

questions.explanationShort: Isolation + movement control is key.
questions.explanationLong: Biosecurity and separation of groups are critical. Blanket antibiotics are not always indicated and may complicate abscess maturation; vaccination is not an immediate substitute for outbreak control.

questions.stem: Equine influenza is mainly spread by:
questions.explanationShort: It’s an airborne/droplet spread respiratory virus.
questions.explanationLong: Equine influenza spreads rapidly via coughing/aerosols and close contact; fomites can contribute but aerosol is primary.

questions.stem: For most competition rules, influenza vaccination boosters are typically required at intervals of around:
questions.explanationShort: Many competition systems require ~6-monthly boosters.
questions.explanationLong: Exam questions often test the concept that competition horses typically need more frequent boosters than leisure horses; exact rules vary by authority, but 6 months is a common requirement.

questions.stem: Most common source of forelimb lameness in horses is:
questions.explanationShort: Most forelimb lameness localises to the foot.
questions.explanationLong: A common exam point: the majority of forelimb lameness cases are distal, with the foot being the most frequent site.

questions.stem: A palmar digital nerve block most specifically localises pain to:
questions.explanationShort: PD block = foot/navicular structures.
questions.explanationLong: Palmar digital blocks desensitise the heel, sole, coffin joint region and navicular apparatus, helping localise distal foot pain.

questions.stem: A horse shows scapular muscle atrophy (“Sweeney”). Most likely nerve injury?
questions.explanationShort: Sweeney = suprascapular nerve injury.
questions.explanationLong: Suprascapular nerve damage causes atrophy of supraspinatus/infraspinatus muscles and shoulder instability.

questions.stem: Stringhalt is characterised by:

options.text: Locked stifle with inability to flex
Painful swelling of the digital flexor tendon sheath

questions.explanationShort: Stringhalt = hyperflexion of the hindlimb.
questions.explanationLong: It is a neuromuscular gait abnormality with exaggerated flexion, often more obvious when backing or turning.

questions.stem: Upward fixation of the patella is best described as:

options.text: Medial patellar ligament hooks over medial trochlear ridge

questions.explanationShort: It’s a mechanical locking over the medial ridge.
questions.explanationLong: The patellar “locking” mechanism fails to release; often managed with conditioning, corrective shoeing, and sometimes medial patellar ligament desmotomy/splitting.

questions.stem: Most common route for septic arthritis in foals:
questions.explanationShort: Foals usually get it via bloodstream.
questions.explanationLong: Failure of passive transfer → septicaemia → joint infection is classic in foals; multiple joints may be affected.

questions.stem: Laminitis pathogenesis most directly involves failure of:

options.text: Lamellar attachment between hoof wall and distal phalanx
Collateral ligaments of the coffin joint

questions.explanationShort: Lamellae fail → P3 can rotate/sink.
questions.explanationLong: Inflammation/metabolic and vascular dysfunction leads to lamellar degradation and separation between the hoof wall and distal phalanx.

questions.stem: Most serious structural consequence of laminitis:

options.text: Coffin joint luxation without lamellar failure

questions.explanationShort: Rotation/sinking of P3 is the major feared complication.
questions.explanationLong: Mechanical failure of lamellae permits displacement of the distal phalanx; this drives chronic pain and poor prognosis.

questions.stem: High ringbone most commonly refers to osteoarthritis of the:
questions.explanationShort: High ringbone = PIP joint OA.
questions.explanationLong: Ringbone refers to osteoarthritis/periostitis around pastern region; high ringbone involves the PIP joint.

questions.stem: Bog spavin is best defined as:
questions.explanationShort: Bog spavin = tibiotarsal effusion.
questions.explanationLong: Bog spavin is a distension of the tibiotarsal joint capsule; it may be incidental or linked to osteochondrosis/synovitis.

questions.stem: A horse with acute, severe lameness improves dramatically after a hoof tester response and paring reveals a tract. Most likely diagnosis?

options.text: Collateral ligament rupture of DIP joint

questions.explanationShort: Classic presentation of hoof abscess.
questions.explanationLong: Solar abscess causes acute severe lameness, focal hoof tester pain, and relief once drainage is established; navicular pathology is typically more chronic.

questions.stem: A horse has “pointing” of a forelimb and pain on deep palpation of the heel region. Which condition is most consistent?
questions.explanationShort: Heel pain + pointing suggests navicular-type pain.
questions.explanationLong: Navicular syndrome often presents with intermittent forelimb lameness, toe pointing, and heel pain; diagnostic blocks often implicate the foot.

questions.stem: The mare is seasonally:
questions.explanationShort: Mares cycle in long daylight months.
questions.explanationLong: Mares are long-day breeders; photoperiod influences melatonin and reproductive cycling.

questions.stem: In mares, ovulation typically occurs:

options.text: 24–48 hours before the end of oestrus

questions.explanationShort: Ovulation is late oestrus.
questions.explanationLong: A classic detail: mares often ovulate near the end of behavioural oestrus, so breeding timing and ultrasound monitoring are important.

questions.stem: Endometrial cups in the pregnant mare primarily produce:
questions.explanationShort: Endometrial cups make eCG.
questions.explanationLong: eCG supports secondary corpus lutea formation and progesterone production indirectly. It has LH-like activity in the mare.

questions.stem: Persistent mating-induced endometritis is most likely in:

options.text: Young maiden mare with good uterine tone
Older multiparous mare with poor uterine clearance

questions.explanationShort: Older mares often clear uterine fluid poorly.
questions.explanationLong: Risk factors include age, poor perineal conformation, pneumovagina, dependent uterus and reduced myometrial contractility → fluid retention after breeding.

questions.stem: Twin pregnancy in the mare most commonly results in:
questions.explanationShort: Mares rarely carry twins to term successfully.
questions.explanationLong: Limited uterine/placental capacity means twins often lead to pregnancy loss or weak foals; early diagnosis and reduction is standard.

questions.stem: Most common infectious cause of abortion in mares (high-yield):
questions.explanationShort: EHV-1 is the classic abortion virus.
questions.explanationLong: EHV-1 can cause abortion storms and also neurological disease; biosecurity and vaccination strategies are commonly examined.

questions.stem: A “red bag” delivery indicates:
questions.explanationShort: Red bag = placental separation emergency.
questions.explanationLong: Premature separation prevents oxygen transfer; prompt incision of the membrane and rapid delivery is essential to prevent hypoxia.

questions.stem: For best passive transfer, a foal should ingest adequate colostrum within:
questions.explanationShort: Gut absorption drops quickly after birth; aim within 6–12h.
questions.explanationLong: IgG absorption declines markedly after ~12 hours and is minimal by 24 hours (gut closure). Early intake is critical.

questions.stem: A foal IgG of 300 mg/dL at 18 hours is best classified as:
questions.explanationShort: <400 mg/dL = severe/complete FPT.
questions.explanationLong: Common cut-offs: >800 adequate; 400–800 partial; <400 complete failure → high sepsis risk and needs plasma/management.

questions.stem: In mares, retained placenta is generally defined as not passed by:
questions.explanationShort: >3 hours is the common definition.
questions.explanationLong: Retained fetal membranes (>3h) increase risk of metritis, endotoxaemia and laminitis; prompt management is important.

questions.stem: Most common cause of non-painful ataxia in young horses (classic exam answer):
questions.explanationShort: Wobbler is a common classic ataxia cause.
questions.explanationLong: Cervical spinal cord compression causes symmetrical ataxia/weakness. EHV-1 can cause ataxia too, but wobbler is a frequent exam staple.

questions.stem: Tetanus most characteristically causes:

options.text: Blindness and seizures as first signs

questions.explanationShort: Tetanus = rigid, spastic signs.
questions.explanationLong: Clostridial toxin blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters → muscle rigidity, ‘sawhorse’ stance, third eyelid prolapse, hypersensitivity.

questions.stem: Most common skin tumour in grey horses is:
questions.explanationShort: Grey horses commonly develop melanomas.
questions.explanationLong: Melanomas are common in older grey horses (perineum, tail base); many are slow-growing but can become malignant.

questions.stem: Sarcoids are best described as:

options.text: Locally aggressive fibroblastic skin tumours associated with bovine papillomavirus

questions.explanationShort: Sarcoids are locally aggressive and linked to BPV.
questions.explanationLong: They rarely metastasise but commonly recur after trauma/incomplete removal; management varies (surgery, topical chemo, immunotherapy).

questions.stem: “Choke” in horses most commonly refers to:
questions.explanationShort: Choke = oesophageal obstruction (not airway).
questions.explanationLong: Horses can still breathe; nasal discharge of feed/saliva is common. Complications include aspiration pneumonia.

questions.stem: The most appropriate immediate management for choke (initial steps) is:

options.text: Force water down the oesophagus quickly
Withhold feed, provide sedation, and consider gentle lavage
Immediate general anaesthesia in all cases

questions.explanationShort: Sedation + gentle approach reduces trauma/aspiration risk.
questions.explanationLong: Avoid forceful fluids. Sedation reduces spasm and facilitates careful lavage; monitor for aspiration pneumonia.

questions.stem: Equine Metabolic Syndrome (EMS) is most strongly associated with:
questions.explanationShort: EMS = obesity/cresty neck + insulin issues.
questions.explanationLong: EMS involves insulin dysregulation, obesity/regional fat, and high laminitis risk—especially in ponies/cobs.

questions.stem: PPID (equine Cushing’s) is due to:
questions.explanationShort: PPID = pars intermedia dysfunction.
questions.explanationLong: Neurodegeneration reduces dopaminergic inhibition → pars intermedia hyperplasia/adenoma → abnormal ACTH/peptide production.

questions.stem: Pergolide is primarily used to treat:
questions.explanationShort: Pergolide is the main drug for PPID.
questions.explanationLong: Pergolide is a dopamine agonist that restores inhibitory control of pars intermedia activity in PPID.

questions.stem: A pony with recurrent laminitis, obesity, and high insulin is best managed long-term with:

options.text: Weight loss program, low NSC diet, controlled exercise when safe

questions.explanationShort: Diet + weight loss is key to reduce insulin and laminitis risk.
questions.explanationLong: EMS management is primarily nutritional: reduce non-structural carbohydrates, promote weight loss, and exercise as tolerated; medical therapy may be adjunctive.

questions.stem: Which equine disease is notifiable in the UK (high-stakes differential question)?
questions.explanationShort: African Horse Sickness is notifiable.
questions.explanationLong: AHS is a high-consequence vector-borne disease with major movement restrictions and reporting requirements.

questions.stem: Most important single biosecurity practice to reduce infectious disease spread on an equine yard:

options.text: Immediate antibiotics for any nasal discharge
Isolation/quarantine of new arrivals with monitoring
Only using one water bucket for the yard

questions.explanationShort: Quarantine new arrivals is the biggest win.
questions.explanationLong: Isolation reduces introduction/spread of respiratory pathogens (strangles, influenza, EHV). Monitor temperature and test when indicated.

questions.stem: Hyperlipaemia is most classically a disease of:

options.text: Obese ponies and donkeys in negative energy balance
Only lactating mares with normal appetite

questions.explanationShort: Fat ponies/donkeys that stop eating = classic.
questions.explanationLong: Hyperlipaemia (fatty liver syndrome) is strongly linked to insulin resistance + negative energy balance, especially in ponies and donkeys.

questions.stem: The defining laboratory abnormality in hyperlipaemia is:
questions.explanationShort: High triglycerides (lipemic blood).
questions.explanationLong: Diagnosis is based on elevated triglycerides; serum/plasma may appear cloudy/milky.

questions.stem: Which is a common risk factor listed for hyperlipaemia?

options.text: Exclusive pasture access with normal appetite

questions.explanationShort: Not eating + stress triggers it.
questions.explanationLong: Negative energy balance triggers fat mobilisation; stressors and concurrent disease are classic triggers.

questions.stem: First-line principle of hyperlipaemia treatment is best summarised as:

options.text: Promote lipolysis to clear fat faster
Restore positive energy balance urgently (nutrition + IV glucose as needed)

questions.explanationShort: Get calories in ASAP.
questions.explanationLong: Successful treatment depends on reversing negative energy balance: feed support + glucose infusion and treat underlying cause.

questions.stem: Heparin may be used in hyperlipaemia primarily to:

options.text: Increase lipoprotein lipase activity and help clear triglycerides

questions.explanationShort: Heparin can support TG clearance via LPL.
questions.explanationLong: Notes describe heparin to increase lipoprotein lipase activity to aid triglyceride removal.

questions.stem: Prognosis in hyperlipaemia is generally:

options.text: Excellent in most cases without urgent action
Poor; improved when voluntary food intake returns
Always good if triglycerides are high
Only poor in horses, not donkeys

questions.explanationShort: Often poor—eating again improves outlook.
questions.explanationLong: Hyperlipaemia can progress to organ dysfunction and death; early intervention and restoring appetite are key.

questions.stem: A typical appearance of plasma/serum in hyperlipaemia is:
questions.explanationShort: Milky blood is a big clue.
questions.explanationLong: Lipemia reflects high circulating triglycerides/VLDLs.

questions.stem: Which statement about equids and fat metabolism supports why hyperlipaemia can be severe?

options.text: Equids have unlimited ketone production capacity
Equids have limited ability to convert NEFAs into ketones, promoting TG accumulation
Equids cannot mobilise fat at all
Equids only store fat in the liver normally

questions.explanationShort: They can accumulate TGs rapidly.
questions.explanationLong: Notes highlight limited metabolic pathways compared with other species, contributing to high TGs and fatty liver.

questions.stem: A donkey on cardboard bedding is at increased hyperlipaemia risk mainly because:

options.text: Ingestion is linked to increased risk (management risk factor)

questions.explanationShort: It’s listed as a risk factor in donkeys.
questions.explanationLong: The notes list bedding type as a risk factor, particularly cardboard where ingestion may occur.

questions.stem: A practical early suspicion trigger for hyperlipaemia is:

options.text: Any thin horse with a good appetite
Any overweight pony/donkey that becomes anorexic and depressed
Any horse with normal plasma and normal liver enzymes

questions.explanationShort: Fat pony/donkey + anorexia = emergency suspicion.
questions.explanationLong: This is a classic exam pattern recognition point and matches the “presumptive diagnosis” description.

questions.stem: Most common internal parasite group in horses is:
questions.explanationShort: Cyathostomins are the commonest.
questions.explanationLong: Notes state >95% of a horse’s parasite burden can be cyathostomins.

questions.stem: A key limitation of FWEC in cyathostomin disease is:

options.text: It detects encysted larvae very well
It cannot identify encysted small redworm larvae
It detects tapeworm better than ELISA

questions.explanationShort: FWEC misses encysted larvae.
questions.explanationLong: Encysted larval burden can be high with low egg output; exams love this trap.

questions.stem: Best method to assess anthelmintic efficacy in horses (per notes) is:
questions.explanationShort: FECRT day 0 and day 14.
questions.explanationLong: Faecal egg count reduction testing is the standard way to check resistance/efficacy.

questions.stem: Which drug is highlighted as the only effective single-dose larvicidal option for encysted cyathostomins?
questions.explanationShort: Moxidectin is the key larvicidal drug.
questions.explanationLong: Notes state moxidectin is the only effective larvicidal drug (single dose) for encysted stages.

questions.stem: Tapeworm Anoplocephala perfoliata is most commonly located at the:
questions.explanationShort: Ileocecal junction.
questions.explanationLong: This location is linked to ileal impactions and ileocecal intussusception risk.

questions.stem: A. perfoliata infection is a significant risk factor for which colic patterns (per notes)?
questions.explanationShort: Spasmodic colic + ileal impaction risk.
questions.explanationLong: Notes describe studies linking intensity of infection with spasmodic colic risk and ileal impactions.

questions.stem: Preferred drug if targeting only tapeworm is:
questions.explanationShort: Praziquantel is the tapeworm-specific go-to.
questions.explanationLong: Pyrantel can also be used (double dose), but praziquantel is preferred when focusing on tapeworm.

questions.stem: Pinworm (Oxyuris equi) most classically causes:
questions.explanationShort: Tail rubbing is the classic sign.
questions.explanationLong: Egg deposition around perineum causes irritation; diagnosis often uses adhesive tape test.

questions.stem: Best practical diagnostic method for pinworm is often:
questions.explanationShort: Tape test is classic for pinworm eggs.
questions.explanationLong: Eggs are laid perianally, so FWEC may miss; tape test improves detection.

questions.stem: Targeted strategic dosing in horses typically uses FWEC and treats only horses above about:
questions.explanationShort: >200 EPG is a common treatment threshold.
questions.explanationLong: Notes describe only treating horses above ~200 EPG to reduce unnecessary anthelmintic use and resistance pressure.

questions.stem: Infundibular caries (IC) is primarily a disorder of:
questions.explanationShort: It affects maxillary cheek teeth infundibula.
questions.explanationLong: Notes describe IC as an insidious disorder of maxillary teeth and a cause of apical infection/fracture.

questions.stem: A primary underlying cause described for IC is:
questions.explanationShort: ICH predisposes to caries.
questions.explanationLong: Incomplete cemental filling leads to caries progression and structural weakness.

questions.stem: Which clinical sign is consistent with significant dental disease including IC?
questions.explanationShort: Quidding is classic for dental pain/problems.
questions.explanationLong: Notes list dysmastication/quidding, weight loss and premature tooth loss as signs.

questions.stem: Best imaging view mentioned for diagnosing IC is:

options.text: CT is mandatory in every case

questions.explanationShort: Open-mouth oblique views are specifically noted.
questions.explanationLong: Oral exam plus open-mouth oblique radiographs are described for diagnosis.

questions.stem: IC grading: Grade 3 implies involvement of:
questions.explanationShort: Grade 3 includes dentine.
questions.explanationLong: Notes outline progression: cementum → enamel → dentine; deeper involvement increases fracture/apical infection risk.

questions.stem: A commonly cited threshold for considering restoration in IC is:

options.text: Only if the horse is <2 years old

questions.explanationShort: Grade 3+ and deep probing can trigger restoration decisions.
questions.explanationLong: Notes specify IC grade ≥3 with at least ~10 mm probing depth as a key decision point.

questions.stem: Infundibular caries can predispose to:
questions.explanationShort: Structural weakening can lead to fracture/apical infection.
questions.explanationLong: This is a core consequence highlighted in the notes.

questions.stem: Which statement is most consistent with IC epidemiology in the notes?

options.text: Common in UK horses (noted as a sizable percentage)

questions.explanationShort: It’s described as common.
questions.explanationLong: The notes describe IC as a common dental disorder in UK horses.

questions.stem: A key prevention/control message for IC is:

options.text: Avoid any dental exams to reduce trauma

questions.explanationShort: Routine dental care matters.
questions.explanationLong: Early detection and monitoring are emphasised; many cases become significant only after progression.

questions.stem: A donkey with premature tooth loss most strongly raises suspicion for:

options.text: Infundibular caries being a key cause

questions.explanationShort: IC is a primary cause of premature tooth loss in donkeys (per notes).
questions.explanationLong: This is a nice exam-style species twist: donkeys feature strongly in the IC notes.

questions.stem: Most common pathological dysrhythmia in the horse is:

options.text: Atrial flutter is always more common than AF

questions.explanationShort: AF is the commonest pathological arrhythmia.
questions.explanationLong: This is explicitly stated as an exam-frequent fact.

questions.stem: First-line pharmacologic cardioversion option described for equine AF is:
questions.explanationShort: Quinidine is the classic drug choice.
questions.explanationLong: Notes describe quinidine sulfate as the pharmacologic option of choice, commonly administered via stomach tube.

questions.stem: Quinidine therapy should generally be given:

options.text: At home without monitoring if the horse is calm
As an outpatient with weekly checks only
In hospital with intensive monitoring due to frequent side effects
Only IM as it cannot be given orally

questions.explanationShort: Needs hospital-level monitoring.
questions.explanationLong: Side effects/toxicity are common; continuous observation is recommended in the notes.

questions.stem: A realistic reason quinidine is given via stomach tube is:

options.text: It is destroyed by stomach acid otherwise
It has a bitter taste and can cause oral irritation
It must be injected into the caecum
It only works if mixed with hay

questions.explanationShort: Bitter taste/oral irritation.
questions.explanationLong: The notes specifically mention this practical administration reason.

questions.stem: Which scenario predicts best cardioversion prognosis with quinidine (per notes)?

options.text: AF >2 years duration and severe structural disease
Very short duration ‘lone AF’ and low resting HR
AF with congestive heart failure signs
AF in a horse with persistent high fever

questions.explanationShort: Short-duration lone AF does best.
questions.explanationLong: Notes mention better response when AF is short duration, lone AF, and resting HR is relatively low.

questions.stem: Which is a reported quinidine adverse effect spectrum in horses?

options.text: Colic, diarrhoea, hypotension, weakness/ataxia, and severe arrhythmias

questions.explanationShort: Wide range including dangerous arrhythmias.
questions.explanationLong: Notes list significant toxicity risk; hence intensive monitoring.

questions.stem: Therapeutic quinidine blood levels described are approximately:
questions.explanationShort: 2–5 µg/L is the noted therapeutic range.
questions.explanationLong: The notes give a narrow therapeutic window around 2–5 µg/L.

questions.stem: If a horse has signs of congestive heart failure, the notes advise:

options.text: Riding improves cardiac output and is recommended
Only change diet; exercise is irrelevant

questions.explanationShort: CHF signs = don’t ride.
questions.explanationLong: This is a practical welfare/safety point directly stated in the notes.

questions.stem: Most common congenital cardiac abnormality stated in the notes is:
questions.explanationShort: VSD is listed as most common congenital abnormality.
questions.explanationLong: This is included as a high-yield factual point in the cardiology notes.

questions.stem: A left-sided systolic murmur differential list in the notes includes:

options.text: Physiological aortic flow, mitral regurgitation, ‘haemic’ murmurs

questions.explanationShort: Those are the listed common causes.
questions.explanationLong: The notes outline typical left-sided systolic murmur causes including physiological flow and MR, plus haemic murmurs.

questions.stem: Correct flow order through equine large bowel is:

options.text: Small intestine → descending colon → caecum → ascending colon
Small intestine → caecum → ascending (large) colon → transverse colon → descending (small) colon
Small intestine → transverse colon → caecum → rectum

questions.explanationShort: SI → caecum → large colon → transverse → small colon.
questions.explanationLong: This is the canonical pathway and is a frequent anatomy exam target.

questions.stem: The pelvic flexure is located between:

options.text: Left ventral colon and left dorsal colon

questions.explanationShort: Pelvic flexure = left ventral → left dorsal.
questions.explanationLong: This landmark is classic for impactions and displacement discussions.

questions.stem: Which section is noted as having taenial bands in the summary?
questions.explanationShort: Left ventral colon has taeniae.
questions.explanationLong: The notes contrast ventral colon (taenial bands) with left dorsal colon (smooth).

questions.stem: The diaphragmatic flexure connects:

options.text: Left ventral to left dorsal colon
Left dorsal colon to right dorsal colon

questions.explanationShort: Diaphragmatic flexure = left dorsal → right dorsal.
questions.explanationLong: Another high-yield flexure identification point.

questions.stem: Which of the following is the best statement about ileal impactions in the parasite section?

options.text: They are unrelated to tapeworm infection
They are a recognised risk associated with Anoplocephala perfoliata
They occur only after quinidine therapy
They occur only in foals <2 weeks old

questions.explanationShort: Tapeworm is linked to ileal impactions.
questions.explanationLong: Notes describe ileal impaction and intussusception risks increasing with tapeworm infection intensity.

questions.stem: A horse with protein-losing enteropathy and watery diarrhoea should raise suspicion for:
questions.explanationShort: Cyathostomins are a classic cause.
questions.explanationLong: Notes state cyathostominosis should be considered in horses with protein-losing enteropathy and watery diarrhoea.

questions.stem: Larval cyathostominosis syndrome is dangerous mainly because:

options.text: Mass emergence can be fatal and is associated with high mortality
It occurs only in very old horses
It is always cured by praziquantel

questions.explanationShort: Mass emergence can be fatal (high mortality).
questions.explanationLong: The notes emphasise potentially fatal consequences and significant mortality with larval emergence.

questions.stem: Which management approach aligns with targeted strategic dosing described in the notes?

options.text: Treat every horse every month regardless of egg counts
FWEC monitoring and treat only higher shedders plus tapeworm ELISA periodically
Never deworm any horse to avoid resistance

questions.explanationShort: Monitor, treat selectively, and include tapeworm testing strategy.
questions.explanationLong: The notes outline a targeted approach using FWEC thresholds and regular tapeworm ELISA (blood/saliva).

questions.stem: Which diagnostic approach is specifically stated as NOT diagnosing larval cyathostominosis syndrome?

options.text: ELISA for IgG(T) antibodies to cyathostomins

questions.explanationShort: FWEC alone isn’t diagnostic for larval disease.
questions.explanationLong: Because encysted larvae may not shed eggs, FWEC can be falsely reassuring.

questions.stem: A correct statement about tapeworm diagnostics in the notes is:

options.text: FWEC is highly reliable alone for tapeworm
ELISA (blood/saliva) is recommended because FWEC is poor for tapeworm
Tape test is best for tapeworm

questions.explanationShort: Use ELISA because FWEC is poor for tapeworm.
questions.explanationLong: The notes highlight FWEC’s limitations and recommend ELISA testing strategies (blood/saliva).
